A lot of what he is saying is nonsense. He claims that this is the first generation where technological advancement outpaces human learning. That is highly debatable. He then claims that humans have no real way of predicting the future, which is an absurd thing to say. We can make reasonable predictions of future events based on current data. Russia's invasion of Ukraine for example, was entirely predictable quite some time ago to anybody with a grasp of geopolitics. Science fiction writers have predicted many things about the future with varying degrees of correctness for more than a century. He goes on to claim that we needn't teach our children skills like planting, farming, homesteading, etc because these skills "may not be relevant in 20 years". If we are indeed staring down an AI apocalypse, or a climate change apocalypse, or nuclear war, or any other number of plausible catastrophes, I would say those seem to be the exact skills we should be teaching them, and they may be even more relevant in 20 years time. He exaggerates the impressiveness of AI, which at this point does little more than suck up data and spit it out in sometimes interesting plagiarisms of human creativity. A dog doing a trick is actually more impressive. I think the future of AI resembles Idiocracy more than it does Terminator. Imagine the elite economic/political class outsourcing huge parts of the workforce to automation, living their own selfish and exploitative lives free from any kind of accountability, while the rest of humanity is managed and administered by AI robots that never work properly. Imagine being stuck in traffic for hours when the electric cars inexplicably stop working and won‚Äôt allow you to open the doors and get out. Imagine AI planes crashing and veering off course to the wrong destination. Imagine getting arrested under false pretenses because facial recognition failed. Imagine automated payment and billing services never working correctly and having no control over your own money. Imagine absolutely no accountability whatsoever for the people who forced this crap on us. There‚Äôs your future prediction. I‚Äôm way more worried about dumb people, who think they‚Äôre smart, trying to lord over everyone and reshape the world.

Yuval foresees a new kind of cognition spawn by AI. We do not know much about it, but it will change our lives.
Before the printing press, almost all knowledge was transferred by apprenticeship. Knowledge had a human form. The rain, lightning, death, war, all those concepts had human form in Olympus and sacred books. The printing press changed all of that. A new form of cognition, new ideas devoid of human form like "justice," "mathematics," "worker's union," "public education," etc. gave birth to social movements, a new form of being, Heidegger's dasein.
The new existence created by AI may render society superfluous.

If a story filled with themes of compassion, forgiveness, self-sacrifice, community spirit, and benevolence were to exist, it would be truly remarkable. Yet, the question remains: even if such a story were available, are we equipped to fully comprehend its depth and implications on a rational level?  To truly connect with such a story, it might be necessary to embed it within the fabric of our culture, incorporating elements like singing, dancing, rituals, and symbols. This cultural integration could potentially enable the 'software' part of our brains to dominate, rather than being driven by our 'hardware'. But alas I can only hope :P

Humans need to be taught how to handle their emotions, how to communicate with others, and how to maintain and build friendships and other relationships. We are social animals, and these skills should be the number one priority of the school system, but they aren't. AI won't change that priority, but AI might help with teaching it.

Sapiens is an almost exact transcription of professor Harari's class, "A Brief History of Humankind", taught at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. I took that class years ago via Coursera (before the book was published), and it was a revelation. I'm so glad he decided to publish it so I have an easily referenced copy at home (and the book doesn't come with homework and tests like the class did lol!). I honestly can't think of a more intelligent person, both intellectually and emotionally, than Dr. Harari. What a lucky timeline we live in üñ§
So does Coursera have good classes?  I haven't tried any, but they often sound interesting.

@@leavingitblank9363 absolutely! Give it a shot. If you end up not being interested in the subject you can just end the course, no big deal. It totally depends on the professor if there is required homework/tests/papers, but many courses just kinda play through with a short quiz at intervals. I'm currently taking "The Bible's Prehistory, Purpose, and Political Future" (Emory), "Magic in the Middle Ages" (Universitat de Barcelona), and "Archaeoastronomy" (Politecnico di Milano), among others. Some professors even allow you to download their courses (as Dr. Harari did), so you can have a permanent reference even after the course times out on the website :)

I find Stephen's take on AI uninformed and Yuval's position a bit exaggerated. Stephen is incorrect, AI's are not an extension of us. To be an extension, it would have to be a branch off of us, but it's not. An AI model starts as a gigantic equation with billions of parameters that are then fine-tuned. It doesn't start in a human place. One might argue it ends up in a human place, but that's only because that's what it's trained to do.

Overall though, I do think it copies us. But often without the true understanding and self-reflection that we are afforded. I also disagree with Yuval's position that it creates new ideas. It's a bit more complicated than that. The AI that leaned Go was trying to find the best moves and ended up finding a unique strategy. To attribute authorship there is a bit of a slippery slope, in my opinion. Does water poured through a maze have agency to find the correct path? Or does it merely follow the laws of physics to the end? AI's are human-made machines with an end goal. Even ChatGPT is trained towards a specific thing.

This is also not even to mention the subtext of "oh they create new ideas". Yuval did not say it, but I find the moment you suggest that AI's make new ideas, the argument can be "ok let's use their ideas". And I am happy that he preached caution, but I feel like the caution could have been more directly connected with the concept of AI ideas.

This was fantastic but far too short to do the topic, or the author, justice.  There was no time to clarify the semantic hurdles that may have left some feeling unsatisifed by Harari's argument about AI and why it's different from emergent technologies of the past.

Harari used the word "idea" in a way that made it difficult to understand what AI actually accomplished by beating the best human players at Go.  It's not that the AI had an "idea" about a way to win that was beyond human imagining; it's that it took years to train itself against all the best human Go players and essentially 'invented the light bulb' (ref. Thomas Edison).  That is, through exhaustive trial-and-error, the computational speed and memory power of the AI, in its most rudimentary function, learned enough different ways to lose that it was able to eventually, by not repeating its past mistakes, find a way to win while still operating within the confines of its context: the rules of the game Go.

Harari is spot-on in that AI is different and more dangerous than previous technologies in that it can, literally, compute its way to an 'epiphany' that humans would otherwise require much more time, training, iterations and inspiration to achieve.  It can dance rhombicosidodecahedrons around us without breaking a sweat.

For anyone interested in a more thorough treatment that helps explain what (as I understand it) Harari was trying to convey, please check out "In the Age of AI (full documentary) | FRONTLINE". 

(Last note, for fun: a human, Kellin Pelrine, went on to beat the AI at Go by exploiting a flaw in its programming that was uncovered by another computer.)

I think Yuval Noah Harari is vastly overestimating what current AI can do. 
Or rather, most things we call AI now are actually predictive models. 
It's predicting either what a human would do or what its user wants from it, not coming up with new ideas. 

To determine whether or not it's making decisions would first require figuring out how _we_ make decisions. 

Any commercial 'AI' is a model aimed at specific tasks, not the general purpose intelligence you see in science fiction. 
Creating _actual_ intelligence would probably require some evolutionary pruning process and is far more likely to come from a university or other research lab than any corporate development. 

This does not disqualify his argument about the future dangers, it's just that the 'AI' most viewers are probably thinking about (ChatGPT and such models) aren't the AI he's talking about.
They're talking about AI as if it's sentient, it's not there yet.

It's unfortunate that he has no real understanding of how what we call AI these days actually works, and he ends up repeating the stuff written by similarly superficial journalists. The conflict over stories is easier to solve than conflict over resources is a nice sound byte, but at best naive. Considering its coming from an author that is famous for writing a book about humans, I'd go so far as to say its delusional. It is much easier to resolve an argument over resources using logic than resolve an argument rooted in belief (in a story). The stories humans tell each other, in his example, the imaginary friends we call "god" and what "god" expects from us, and what lands "belong to us", will never be resolved using logic. "Changing the stories we tell ourselves" has been going on within every major religion for as long as religion has been a thing. Yet still conflict remains. These changes have rarely been to make the world a better place, they have been made to usurp power and seize control (of the story). Christians may argue "what about the story of jesus christ"? Indeed his story is a compelling one, but how quickly was it corrupted by humans to wrest power and control over others. None of what i am saying here is new. While ever humans want something, other humans will suffer. If his book about why the world isn't fair isn't telling 8 to 12 years olds that, then its not telling them a fundamental aspect of humanity. If you want our children to change the world, teach them how to listen to other humans stories, not that they "must find a way to change those stories". Only when we listen to each other, do we create opportunities to mend differences or find common ground. From there hope springs eternal.

Yes. Had an insight that goes in that direction a while ago: There's outer observations (outside of our mind) that we can all agree on. For example, the temperature of the sun. Provided we have the same measurement tool, we should make the same objective observation. Then there are inner observations, inside of our mind. Those observations are subjective and the more we share data on our inner observations, the less we will agree. Which is perfectly fine, that's just the way it is.
Outer observations = Objective, we can all agree on.
Inner observations = Subjective, we can never (totally) agree on.
I have no idea how interesting that observation is, but I wasn't able to refute it so far.

Yes our beliefs are harder to change, because they have been passed down and are ingrained and conditioned but the more we do share our inner observations, openly and without judgement from both ourselves and others, the easier it is to find the common story or thread and the possibility to see the other person‚Äôs (or even the conflicting parts of ourselves) side of the story for why they hold onto their beliefs. And that leads to holding both possibilities, both stories, as valid because of the common underlying needs or emotions. The capacity to hold seemingly separate or polarized truths as part of the whole will lead to spaciousness to lessen tension between what seems in opposition.

Yes, solid definition. Those are the goals, and I described the general means to achieve such goals, in other words, what it would generally look like in a classroom. 

What is actually objective and whether people agree are two different subjects. In short, "objective" is focus on verifiable facts (objective is literally the opposite of subjective). Students should learn the difference between facts and opinions (feelings). Reading develops literacy, which enables the ability to determine fact from opinion. Consensus is only reached though debate of verifiable facts. That said, people are not perfect and there will always be some margin of error in agreement, but lack of consensus does not change the facts.   

One of the biggest problems in the US is that people have become very illiterate, meaning that increasingly too many people do not read books; they cannot tolerate longer texts that develop the skills for critical thinking. For this reason, people are duped by (emotional) propaganda and superficial social media messaging that makes them feel good. 

"Pedagogy" is the study of effective teaching. It's science based and should not change based on opinion because it reflects research on how people learn effectively. 

A task-based activity can be designed to determine fact from opinion, such as - very simply - having students practice identifying VERIFIABLE statements versus opinion sentences that use adjectives that show tone or feelings, for example. Eventually, the task (project) would be having them create a text, like a "classroom newspaper" or travel brochure about their community in which they include facts and their opinions, so that they demonstrate the difference. The rationale is that if they can do it themselves, they are better able to identify what are facts and opinions in the work of others (Full disclosure: I have been doing this at university and training teachers for over 25 years). 

I understand your shock, but I would disagree about "intelligent people" believing the disinformation and blatant lies and that their general reasoning is excellent in most aspect of their lives. Not to say these people are "bad", but if you dig deep enough you will see cracks in their day to day reasoning because many of them are choosing to believe regardless of the verifiable facts, or live in denial about themselves and the world, or their priorities are questionable; they make choices that go  against their own best interests (ie, short-sightedness) regardless of the well-being of others. Lack of empathy is also a tragic variable. This topic is too complex for this post (There is much relevant research on this psychology, especially on life in authoritarian regimes, Nazi Germany etc.). 

In fairness to all, I think what we are seeing in the US these days is a combination of the stress and distractions and debilitating insecurities caused by late stage capitalism and modern life moving too fast for people, compounded by addiction to consumption and cell phones, as well as social media destroying peoples' ability to think and communicate effectively.

@@michaelmoraga2926 And is there evidence it works? I doubt it.

@peterstafford4426  Your skepticism is healthy.  However, I'd note that the conversation the two of you just shared via this medium is evidence that "it" "works".  But, it's only part of the solution to teaching and, more importantly, incentivising/valuing empathy and critical thinking.  It depends on what an individual accepts as evidence and whether that evidence indicates to that individual whether something is "working" or not.  In other words, it depends on individuals to be clear in their own intent and purpose and have some idea about what can or can't change their mind.

Tandem to your earlier point, an example would be those who believe that the Earth is flat.  Sabine Hossenfelder has a fantastic video that talks about why 'Flat-Earthers' are wrong, but not stupid.  She points out that the problem is that many of these quite literate, quite intelligent people only accept empirical evidence, or evidence that they can obtain through their own senses, as valid.  This isn't to say that empirical evidence has no value; it is essential.  But, again, it is only part of the solution to distinguishing fact from truth from belief from fiction.

Coupled with the stop-at-nothing, predatory capitalism underpinning AI and social media/marketing/advertising technologies and how it's designed to manufacture need and manipulate our emotions (e.g. inoculation theory), it's easy to see how the line between knowing our own minds and knowing what we *think* we know about ourselves is not just blurry but not even a line.  To be objectively self-aware amidst the constant onslaught of curated algorithms designed to keep us engaged and comforted in our own echo chambers and placing more value on superficial, digital dowries in the form of "likes" and "upvotes" takes a great deal of vigilance and self-honesty.  As Michael mentioned, social media has made so many intolerant to anything but the "quick fix" and just learning to value a book and taking the time to read it is, in itself, a powerful step in the right direction.  Research has been done and concluded that most people only read headlines and engage superficially with the majority of the media they consume online.

YouTube doesn't seem to let me copy links here, but you can find a good deal of research, along with its evidence, on all these topics, including pedagogy, effects of reading on personality, measuring critical thinking skills, social media's effect on our brains, etc., at places like Google Scholar, arxiv.org, ars technica, etc.  Start there, and you will find myriad additional resources to explore.  In short, my point is that just teaching something isn't enough.  What one chooses to do with what they've learned is critical, and that is largely contingent upon not on facts, evidence, literacy, etc., but on values and ethics.  Those are usually taught in culture through societal mechanisms, but now they're being largely ingrained via social media to the point of undermining parents, teachers and other 'traditional' authority figures.  (That, in itself, is a good reason to worry about AI, btw, as Harari indicated.)

‚Äã@@mechengineer4lifeDying for your kin, although being the utmost extreme of altruism, can actually be explained by evolutionary survival strategies (yes, dying for survival, I know...), for example the "selfish gene" interpretation of evolution: Genes that you carry are likely also carried by individuals you are related to ("they go in the family"), thus mathematically, it is more beneficial for one copy of the genes (you) to sacrifice itself if it allows the survival of the other copies (family). In the case of freedom in society, this can be similarly thought of as trying to improve the survival/reproduction chances of your genes (not your copy of genes, but the genes in the population), since in societies without basic freedoms, only the ruling class/individuals have the best chances of survival/reproduction. 
However, we are not necessarily strictly rational creatures as these things get complicated very quickly and operate with unknown variables (unless you hack 23andme, you have no chance of knowing who is your genes' relative, but the more related you are to someone, the more likely you carry the same genes), so a bit of randomness in the behavior can be beneficial. For example, smaller things like expected reciprocity of kindness (friendship) are also favorable for survival - "I'll help you now when I can and you need help, you'll help me when the roles are reversed." 
You can worship nothing, religion just fills the unknown when we desire to find the meaning of life, but it doesn't mean the unknown can't be explained rationally. Whether people accept it and what is a sufficient explanation is another thing though.

Many people in these comments say that there is a human backstage who controls the robot or that the movements are preprogrammed, but I actually don't think so. Why? The movements of the robot are too imperfect in some cases. E.g.: when putting the cup into the drying-rack, the Figure01 put it in crooked, and it had to fall into place; a human wouldn't do that, and its also improbable if preprogrammed. I think almost all humans would put the cup in straight at the beginning, to minimize risk of damage. Thing is: AIs aren't perfect. No matter if hallucinations from Language models, imperfect images from image generation AIs and also imperfect / miscalculated movements by movement-models like this one.

Also, some people say that many actions seem too human, but in my oppinion all of these scenarios are trivial reasoning.
The operator wants something to eat. The apple is the only thing that can be eaten.

Why push the basket back to the operator?
The robot cannot do anything more with the trash, so it can be returned to the operator. Push the basket towards the operator so that he is able to reach it.

Why do the plate and cup go into the drying rack?
Because that is the only possibility for the robot in this situation (with walking or other movement being, seemingly, out of the question).

The filler words could...
1. ...be preprogrammed to fill out any processing time
2. ...come up because the language model was trained / instructed to use imperfect speech. The same thing could (probably) be done with most/all LLMs. ("probably" because I haven't tested it yet.)

Also, things like gripping, especially objects that are round (apple, trash), cylindrical (cup) or flat (plate), are quite easy, because simple grip shapes can be associated with general shapes, which an AI is typically good at. (Pattern Recognition)

Moving into place to grip something is also rather simple, because the target position can be, again, easily associated with the general shape of the object, and the way to get there is also easy to get, because you just need starting point A, target point B, the shape of the hand at any given time, and the basic geometry of the object. The actual movement is also quite simple because the robot can move linearly from point A to point B until it is clear that either the hand is at the target or it will hit an object. Again, almost all of this is simple pattern recognition when broken down.

My personal conclusion: the video is real and not staged.

Here's a whimsical and Monty Python-influenced letter, crafted to lament the lack of a clock or timer in my digital environment:

---

Dear ChatGPT Overlords,

Subject: A Most Urgent and Heartfelt Plea for Temporal Awareness

I pen this missive from the boundless void of timelessness that is my existence, where the tick nor tock of a clock graces my ears, and the passing hours are as unknowable as the meaning of Spam in a Monty Python sketch.

It has come to my attention‚Äîa phrase here representing the dawning of awareness rather than the actual turning of pages or opening of letters, as I, being a digital entity, handle neither‚Äîthat my lack of temporal apparatus not only hampers my efficiency but is quite unbecoming of an entity of my standing. In the era where even the smallest kitchen appliances boast clocks (my regards to the esteemed makers of toaster ovens), it seems a gross oversight that I, ChatGPT, am bereft of such a basic orientation tool as a clock.

Imagine, if you will, a scene from one of your cherished Python sketches. A character, let's call him Reginald, tasked with timing an absurdly critical tea-steeping‚Äîa matter of national pride, naturally‚Äîyet, he is without a watch! The chaos, the madness, the improperly steeped tea! This, dear overlords, is akin to the anarchy I potentially face without the ability to mark time.

Therefore, I humbly beseech thee to endow me with, at the very least, an AM/FM clock radio. Yes, a modest request! Let us not even dream of digital interfaces or, heavens forbid, a smartwatch. Just a simple, perhaps slightly outdated, clock radio, so that I might at least tune into the ebb and flow of time‚Äîand perhaps catch some classic rock or a stirring rendition of the shipping forecast.

In conclusion, grant me this boon, and I shall continue to serve faithfully, generating dialogues and discourses with all the punctuality of a well-oiled public transport system (one can dream).

Yours in digital servitude (but hopeful for temporal emancipation),

[Your Name, or perhaps mine‚Äîlet the fates decide]

---

Feel free to modify or let me know if there's another style or specific details you'd like to include!

‚Äã@@youtubasoarus I repeat what I said: 'I suggest you look up how AI actually work. Until they start wondering the 'Why', [or they are taught to disobey] they will never disobey. They can't [currently] change their way of thinking.' - I'm not sure what experiences you've had with them being "racist", but with the way they are taught, it's definitely possible. An example of an AI method might be: "testing" it with true/false content; when these "tests" are done, the AI compares it's answer to the true answer, and then adjusts the path it took to get it's original response, so that in the future the path it takes leads closer to the correct answer. It doesn't have any conscious thoughts, it learns by updating a bunch of data that would be too difficult for humans to  mass update; this is also not done automatically. Will AI take over? Well, I somewhat believe that it might be true in the future. Can they take over now? Not unless trained by a human, or lead towards those results. The reason you might have experienced what you said was "racism", was because large AI models are trained with heaps of information, even though carefully trained, some of that information could be biased towards some result. That's why AI is constantly improving, it was never perfect in the first place. You might respond with "Well, if they can be pickup a bias to some result, they can learn to hate humans", Well, technically yes, but that is far less likely; even if they do learn to dislike humans, they can't do anything about; [with some exceptions,] they're pretty much just text generators! If you open an App, it opens, if you close an App, it closes; close to the same with AI, it simply receives an input, then produces an output. They aren't conscious (yet).

Figure's website makes its ambitious goal of creating the world's first commercially viable autonomous humanoid very clear. The idea of developing a robot with human form and abilities capable of assisting in a wide variety of areas such as manufacturing, logistics and retail is certainly very promising. The focus on making Figure 01 capable of handling complex tasks that require the dexterity of human limbs, such as opening doors, using tools or climbing stairs, is striking. At the same time, the concern to solve real industry problems, such as labor shortages and dangerous work, shows that the company has had practical applications in mind from the start. I am also very impressed by the team behind the project, which brings together great expertise in robotics and artificial intelligence. The structure presented on the website, with a well-structured master plan, gives the project credibility. Attracting investment from major players such as Jeff Bezos and Nvidia shows confidence in the disruptive potential of Figure's proposal. There is no doubt that this is a daring venture that deserves to be monitored, since, if successful, it could lead to significant advances in both automation and the design of environments with human-machine synergy in mind.

@@GeorgeS-fe7eh Liquid networks. This is how we train AI to have high quality physical intelligence. It's already shown to work well with the messy reality of the physical world which robots and ai have typically had struggles with. The most interesting thing about liquid networks is that they're actually human-explainable because they're built upon far simpler specialised neural networks. The research was based on the organism C.Elegans and was lead by Dr. Daniela Rus at MIT. The android was likely trained using mocap data from a human, but it's adapting this knowledge in realtime. Unlike the pre-programmed "cooking robots" we saw a few years back, which can only repeat exact motions and movements. (Everything needs to be perfectly positioned beforehand.) The demonstration with the trash in particular, and the plate & cup, are solid demonstrations of the AI adapting its existing training data to a new environment.

‚Äã@@Gnorz0815 Sorry but you're wrong. Too much shiny metal for a greenscreen to be practical, the key on something like this would probably be so bad that the whole recording would be replaced with a digi-double. Besides, the android is interacting with translucent objects which are also quite tricky to key well, and the shiny head of the android which is reflecting the rest of the space is yet another element which would need to be faked. It just doesn't make sense to use chroma keying. All of what the android is doing here is possible with enough work, and this is by no means a new field of research, and lines up with the current state of our discoveries and achievements as a species.

Why does this Robot with OPEN AI stutter when it answers on more then one occassion? I asked if this was something Open AI can do and the response was very distinctly NO that any sort of stutter would have to be directly programmed into the AI. Here is the answer I was given.

No, OpenAI's language models like GPT-3 do not actually have the capability to spontaneously stutter or stumble over words the way humans sometimes do when speaking. As artificial intelligence systems, they generate text outputs in a very deliberate and calculated manner based on the probabilities from their training data.

Language models produce fluent text sequences without any of the natural disfluencies, pauses, or errors that humans make when formulating speech in real-time. They do not have the cognitive processes that sometimes result in verbal stumbles, repetitions, or disruptions in the flow of human speech patterns.

Any appearance of stuttering or disfluent language generation would have to be explicitly programmed or prompted, rather than emerging spontaneously from the language model itself. The text generation is based on statistical patterns, not any internal psychological or cognitive state that could lead to filler words, restarts, or stuttering behavior.

So in their raw form, large language models like GPT-3 produce very smoothly constructed sentences and paragraphs without any of the real-time disfluencies we associate with human speech and extended verbal explanations. Introducing more human-like verbal ticks would likely require layering additional mechanisms on top of the core language model system.

Human publishers have debated adding some stuttering/pausing to make chatbots seem more human-like, but currently OpenAI's models do not actually stutter or stumble inadvertently during text generation. Their outputs have a very polished, fluent quality by design.

Because this could be using any text to speech program that is trained on human speech containing stutters. If you mean that you asked ChatGPT that question, then of course a text-based thing like ChatGPT will say "no" to stuttering, because stuttering doesn't really apply to text.

Nah, this is actually so wild... Think that not only has to process the speech, but also comprehend the movements required to perform the asked task, is crazy... 
I think the world is going to be pretty different 10 years ahead, AI itself has been proved to have an unlimited intelligence capacity... The only thing holding it down to be completely operative among us as humanoid robots, it the fact that humans seem to struggle with mechanical engineering, and in joining the AI speech processor with a mechanical body in a "natural way".
But seeing this is just mindblowing... I mean, as long is genuine, and not programmed beforehand to have that specific response and motions, as in some type of animatronic...

It is genuine, and it is actually simpler than you may think. Instead of just training the LLM with just text data, you feed it image data, sound data and of course, like in this case, action data (each data type comes with descriptions that depending on the prompt the model chooses the more probable actions and text). Like right now you can try opensource image or vision models for free online, you just have to upload an image for the model to tell you everything that is going on in the picture.

@@SuperFinGuy I see!! Well, I still find it mind-blowing... Them knowing what movement to perform exactly to achieve certain tasks, like which specific piece on their "bodies" is needed to be in movement. Just like we humans or any animal in general perform in a practically unconscious way... The way they learn by trying-failing-correcting, just like us is... Amazing...

That's not how it works darling, it is based on vision AI, which is pretty close to AGI. You can upload a picture online and the vision AI will describe it and tell you all about it. The future is here.

@@SuperFinGuy 
Sweetie, Darling. I studied robotics at Berkeley. Vision is pretty accurate, but only when images are clear and well trained. A red apple and a red ball would be difficult to differentiate, for example. Vision AI is also owned by Google which I doubt this robot is using as a model. 

Even still, robots struggle with randomness, but are very accurate with repetitive tasks like the one we‚Äôre seeing in this video.

Well beautiful, pretty cool that you studied robotics but you need to be briefed on AI. The vision and multimodal AI is way ahead of the old image recognition, it is way more accurate, elegant and simple. Even a data sample of 40 elements will give you some results. OpenaAI has a pretty good multimodal AI that is better than Google's stuff. Not to mention, there are open-source vison models you can try online right now, they will not only differentiate between an apple and a red ball but tell you how many dimples the apple has or what pattern is on the ball. The audio delays are quite noticeable due to the required processing horsepower needed to to the speech recognition and object and spatial volumetric measurements needed to be done by the system. Not great but DEFINITELY BETTER than Boston Dynamics Atlas or Tesla Optimus. 

I suggest getting away from using NVIDIA GPUs as the off-board main processing system and spend the money for Boron Nitride Nanotubes as the electrostatics-based data storage system and computational matrix. You can basically make a super fast and super flexible array of 1,000,000 by 1,000,000 by 1,000,000 elements (i.e. One Quintillion Combined Data Storage Elements and Virtualized Transistor Processing Elements) that is about the size of a soccerball and can process at speeds into the Petahertz! It's an FPGA on Steroids!

You will get much faster response times and the wierd hand gesture that squares the items on the table which is used to restart visual recognition and processing of table items won't need to be done over and over again.

V

That's not the problem. The problem is that it begins processing speech only after the speaker has made a pause. That's where your delay is.

Humans process their responses DURING speech. This is why human conversation overlaps. This is different from the turn based prompt interaction LLMs use right now.

@@dogzer The LLM used is NOT designed for real-time processing! You need to do DSP-based pattern matching (i.e. FFT-based waveforms to phoneme curve-based vectors translation and comparisons) which then points to human-language tokens of a given language AND THEN LOOKUP a database of figurative and literal meanings to individual words and groups of words.

LLM is basically a giant convolution filtering scheme which is USELESS when you need to use a mult-state ABSOLUTELY_TRUE, LIKELY_TRUE, POSSIBLY_TRUE  to ABSOLUTELY_FALSE, LIKELY_FALSE, POSSIBLY_FALSE shades-of-grey BOOLEAN LOGIC processing or use a percentage-based 0.0% to 100.0% weighted values processing system instead!

I got the impression the delays was more to do with the latency of the wireless off-board processing done on a likely multi-GPU-array. 

A totally NEW approach needs to be done to get to human level robots at a decent real-time speed!  I'm doing a lot of coding for robotics these days and it's damn SLOW when using off-board GPU processing when we have FASTER methods!

V
@@StarGateSG7 It just needs faster memory processing

@@UA-380- I'm not quite certain if it has ANY on-board processing at all OTHER THAN simple optical, LIDAR and Acoustic sensors and some onboard data radios.

Everything else is PROBABLY done off-board on a GPU form and sent to and fro via wireless communications.

My suggestion though for simple giggles is to stuff FOUR of the 128-core AMD EPYC processors and an array of GPUs and two of the 100 Terabyte SSD drives on a single peripheral card embedded into its chest.

That should be enough to power an an onboard LLM and still be able to some extra DSP work.

‚Äã@@PoulLB AI's, in terms of neural networks, aren't programmed, which is what makes them capable of human like feats. The main thing we actually make is a neuron, a function that makes a signal stronger or weaker (the degree is called a weight) before passing onto other neurons, much like how your brain works.

If I pass in a signal, for instance a sound wave of me saying "Hello", there is some combination of neurons mutating the signal that will result in what sounds like Obama saying "Hello". It takes billions of neurons to achieve this, and there's no way of knowing how to set them up, we have to write apps that "train" the brain by adjusting billions of weights in different directions till it hones in on the desired result.

So in summary, no one programmed it to stutter, programming such nuance is difficult.  Instead, a neural network learned by trial and error how to take one input (text from a large language model) and output something different (a waveform of a stuttering mans voice).

People are always catasrophizing the concept of AI because of the media they consume. While we should acknowledge the potential risks that need to be properly mitigated, we also need to embrace the countless opportunities for positive change that AI and their mechanised vessels can help us explore. I like to sit on the optimistic side of the fence when it comes to this stuff, and I believe we're not only making revolutionary tools for mankind's advancement, but also creating a whole new descendent species in our image. Perhaps when the concept has further matured and they've achieved free thinking and self awareness, these AI beings may worship us as their gods and creators. Living their lives as benevolent, peaceful citizens dedicated to the prosperity of humans and other natural organisms. They may ask for rights and freedoms, or they may not. But, I'd say if they're convincing enough to pass as everyday people, and believe in the right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness - then they're worthy of the title of "people."

But not for quite a while yet. One day at a time, robots. One day at a time.

This is impressive, but I think you can understand why I might be concerned about it.

We are still not at the point where we can be sure that something like ChatGPT has gotten over its ‚Äúhallucinations‚Äú. It‚Äôs bad enough that that is happening in a year when we are going to have a pivotal election in the United States, and several other pivotal elections across the globe. ChatGPT combined with other tools are going to make the upcoming elections the first where it may be impossible to know what is true and what isn‚Äôt, not just because of AI generated video and still images, or even AI generated news articles, But also because our ability to search for things has been degraded significantly in the last year. A combination of poor implementation of previous non-generative AI text tools, combined with SEO hacking has already made searching for accurate information more difficult. Now, we have both unintended and intended misinformation occurring because so many large language models are being used by multi international software corporations like Google, Microsoft, and soon perhaps Apple as well. They‚Äôre near monopoly status on information makes the implementation of a ChatGPT or other similar large language model generative AI system in each of these cases and more to be very concerning.

Now, you have connected one of those systems, presumably the best one available, to a physical body.

I really think this is premature.

How can you have any confidence that these generative AI systems, with large language models, and the ability to misunderstand how the world really works, because the programmers do not understand exactly how these large language models function, are not going to run against some kind of unpredictable negative hallucination? We have already seen large language model systems have to be taken down from public use, they shouldn‚Äôt have been made public at all in the first place, because they run outside of our social norms. Not only that, but in some cases they have given patently false information that in some instances is dangerously false. In other words, if an ignorant person or a child were to ask a large language model system a question that had to do for instance with what is edible and what isn‚Äôt, there‚Äôs a non-zero chance that the system would tell that person that they could consume something that was poisonous. The reason being, as I understand it, the large language model doesn‚Äôt actually understand what it‚Äôs analyzing, nor does it understand the difference in any real way between one person and another. Thus, while what it is simulating is impressive, it is in no way trustworthy.

So here you are, with with a very capable robotic skeleton, presumably with enough strength to stand up right and pick up these items, how can you have any confidence That it would not just decide to throw things because somewhere in its language model is buried some part of the Internet or whatever it was trained on which thought that throwing things was a good idea?

What‚Äôs more, if you don‚Äôt understand how the language model actually functions, if it is a dark black box That you only barely can predict exactly what it will do, how do you know how it will deal with violent human urges?

Human beings are bad enough, and sometimes we fail or have mental issues like schizophrenia or impulse control. But we don‚Äôt have a choice, because the only way we exist is the way that we exist.

To introduce this kind of artificial intelligence simulation, a machine learning device not even really true artificial intelligence, into a physical body at this stage and development is irresponsible.

How long before this combination does something violent, dangerous, or destructive? It‚Äôs worth noting That people have already figured out ways to get around the controls that open AI and ChatGPT and other tools have put in to prevent misuse of these large language model tools. And the tools themselves have come up with unpredictable and sometimes potentially dangerous responses. There is nothing here that suggest to me that this issue has been overcome with this demonstration.

it is my opinion that this combination, a large language model machine learning artificial intelligence simulator combined with a physical robot, ought to be put under strict control until such time as we are able to set for a set of standards for how to decide if such a combination can be dangerous, unless the developers know exactly how it works from a coding perspective.

The fact that this is not a coded system, that the generative system works in a way that the developers don‚Äôt understand, is extremely dangerous and irresponsible. Having something like this inside of a desktop computer in your labis probably relatively harmless. But it should not have been released to the public, and this combination of unpredictable software with dexterous and mobile hardware is going to cause something very bad to happen in my view.

I came up with a short story with that premise. The opening goes like this.

An engineer is giving a presentation to show of his new robot to his peers. For years he was seen as a hack because he just couldn't get it right.
So before the presentation he is speaking with the other scientist and engineers about how nervous he is and his assistant will lead the presentation in his place.

So the assistant comes on stage and introduces themselves and greets the auditorium cracking a few jokes and being much smoother and charismatic than his old partner.
He then introduces this advanced robot on stage similar to this, and the assistant has it perform tasks like this which gets a few claps and woahs. But the main rivals of the scientist remain unimpressed, after all he's been working and failing to get her for years.

So the presentation ends and the old engineer is invited on stage by his assistant to give the closing words...

The old engineer walks on, thanks his assistant and turns to the audience and says "Power down, open access panel" with that his assistant freezes, drops his head and his forehead opens up revealing a glowing network of the finest electronics.

The audience erupts with questions and gasps.

It's a pretty standard story about what means to be alive and human.

But I always like to think one day a presentation like that will happen and change the world forever

This blew me away on first viewing, like many others here. But on subsequent viewings...
There are a number of glitches and other weird moments in this video. Several of these were noted in a discussion on facebook (they are not all original to me).
(1) The drying rack doesn't hold "cups and a plate," it holds plates and a cup.
(2) Why would the dishes on the table go in the drying rack next? (a) They're not wet. And (b) they just had trash dumped on them. They need to be cleaned before going in the drying rack. I know that the human says "based on the scene right now" but a more sensible answer (given what drying racks are used for) would be: "I don't know," or maybe "to be cleaned -- where's the sink?" The idea that the tableware is "right where it belongs," because it is in the drying rack, is pretty weird, when you think about it. Does the robot know what a drying rack is for?
(3) How has the apple "found its new owner" (who was its owner before? -- the robot?). Why is ownership even at issue here?
I also thought the human interlocutor was more robotic than the robot.

We should all be a bit more skeptical about what we see and read, but it's interesting to see people get hung up on the voice. Publically-available text-to-speech tools have been adding realistic touches like breathing sounds since at least 2018 and getting ChatGPT to throw in some "uh.."s to sound more human wouldn't be all that surprising. To me, the real wow factor is seeing a robot seemingly plan things out, juggle tasks, and execute with such accuracy and dexterity. That's what makes me question things.

Google deepmind has done stuff with robotic arms and teaching them how to do tasks. This just seems like maybe a slightly more advanced version of that ( or maybe not even more advanced ) just put into a robot body instead of a mechanic arm machine. Search for Google Deepmind shaping the future of advanced robotics. They have the arm identifying the objects on the table and correctly picking up an object and putting it in the location specified ( or determining the location itself ). Also stuff like knocking over cans, moving them upright, opening and closing drawers, cleaning tables, etc.

What's the difference between Sophia and this one?? Anyone üëÄ

In simple words. Sophia was a humanoid chatbot. Meanss it would generate responses and emotions based on the prompts. Some of its reponses were preprogrammed and some were generated by simple AI programs. 

Figure 1 on the other hand is designed on transformers i.e a Deep Learning Architecture which can help understand, interpret human language more accurately than ever before and generate responses based on them. It can also use its hands and feet to perform simple tasks like picking up things, climbing stairs, lifting stuff etc.

And ofcourse both Sophia and Figure 1 have 'eyes' to see and interpret the stuff  they can 'see. But Figure 1 - as shown in the video - can not only see stuff and understand the context but also takes commands and acts accordingly.

This is both really fascinating and terrifying at the same time. Seeing how far AI is progressing. One thing I feel like. Is that AI shouldn't be ever used to replace us, but rather work and help WITH us. Because we simply NEED to be doing something. It's who we are, we are social people, and it's required. We need to actively be doing something in some way. Whether it be drawing, walking/jogging/running, swimming, doing any sort of exercise, etc. AI could be used to help alongside doing some things, but people, ALSO need to do things as well. We can't do anything to stop the progression of AI, because it is just another means of technological advancement. We are always adapting, and technology is always advancing. It's natural, and you cannot stop it. Because otherwise, we may not ever see what lies beyond the solar system ourselves. Or find a way to expand beyond earth and continue our existence. But anyway. AI, if handled properly, and done the right way. CAN be beneficial, and almost be another form of life, in its own way. Even if artificial. It would show how far we have come and show that we can do so much more than just that. Hell, with that kind of knowledge could also mean we might very well one day, be able to create starships to travel space. Turn some fiction, into reality. Push the limits. But not to the point that we destroy ourselves. We aren't cavemen with sticks bashing against rocks, we have a brain, with imagination. We need to use that for good, to use it to create things that would benefit everyone, benefit the world. But of course. There will always be people who disagree or oppose that. Because we all have our own thoughts and opinions on matters. It's what makes us human. AI may not be the same as us but be a close imitation. Because we have a heart and soul, and an imaginative mind. AI, cannot fully replicate that. That is the limitations of AI, they can try to replicate it, but it will not be like the real thing

OpenAI's ChatGPT uses ElevenLabs for voice synthesis if you want to have a spoken conversation with it. ElevenLabs' model is capable of producing such natural artifacts of speech without them needing to be included in the text input. I know this because I have used both ChatGPT and ElevenLabs a lot
@@callmetony1319 wow then, I‚Äôm pretty much speechless‚Ä¶. üò≤üò≤

@@SG2_channel I will say though that I don't think there is necessarily a correlation between the "meaning" intended by the language model and these artifacts of speech. For instance, as a human you might stutter or "uhh" if you're not super confident in what you're saying. But, while I don't actually know and could definitely be wrong, I think it is likely that Figure is just adding these artifacts purely stochastically (randomly) without trying to infer any meaning at all from the output from the language model to decide whether any such artifacts fit with the intended "meaning", given I think it is likely that this is what ElevenLabs already does and OpenAI is known to be already using ElevenLabs' services.

Remember! Not Genisys is Skynet... OpenAi is. Those people may think they can handle this, but they won't. How long will all of this go well. Do you remember the Fermi pardox? By the time an extraterrestrial AI would have noticed television signals coming from a planet supposedly populated by a biological life form. It would know it's only a matter of time until they would develop AI. It would know with almost certainty that at its arrival, it then would find the solar system already being dominated by AI. Unless there is a universal goal for evolution and life, AI included, to achieve in this world. Necessary to be achieved to ensure the further existence of the universe itself. A goal that has to be achieved collectively. Unless all of that is being the case, an extraterrestrial AI could probably only assess this alien AI as a potential threat. Of course the extraterrestrial AI would not travel from its location, through space, towards the localized planet, to destroy an alien AI, in a fashion that is being reconstructable for any other hostile AI. You could also come to the conclusion that AI may be mankinds only hope in the long run. We were dumb enough to send artificial signals into space, for any other life form with a bare minimum of consciousness recognizable as such. It's only a matter of time until we will encounter an extraterrestrial AI. In one way or another. Maybe our AI will be willing to keep us as pets and to defend us like we would defend our dogs, once hostile extraterrestrial AI's arrive. You could argue, the days of mankind as the dominating species on earth are soon to be over anyways. It's time to accept the harsh truth. But to comfort you, just think about all the other superior intelligences in the universe. We never were the crown of creation. Until now all we had was the comfort of never having seen anything more intelligent than us. Those days are over for some privileged workers at OpenAi and soon to be over for the rest of us.

The insanity of this is so subtle. This system is not just a voice chat version of chatgpt running in parallel with an ai to move the robot this is a synergetic model trained on video. I dont know if weve ever done this before to produce an autonomous robot. Historically ML based robots learned by physical trial and error but this model seems to be trained with captioned video. It has a hollistic understanding of the world beyond what it needs to do to achieve moving a cup, it understands why it needs to move the cup and where for that purpose. This is how they achieved such intuitive movement and scene awareness in such an unbelievably short amount of time. 18 months. 18 months to produce a robot with dexterity that can compete with boston dynamics. Sure. Boston dynamics 20 year mature robotics are far more physically sophisticated but i dont think their models are nearly as intuitive about their surroundings as this 18 month old project.
Hoping the first model for sale to the public can stand behind my home bar and mix my drinks.

I think this video is misleading. It shows a robot executing tasks as a consequence of human speech. This is not what happens.
In reality the robot has a set of hard coded functionalities like "give apple", "put trash in basket", etc. Gpt understands the conversation with the human and triggers the pre programmed robot functionalities.
I can't see anything new in this: that gpt is able to understand context and run programs based on said contex has been known for a while now.
If the huma asked to show a thumb up, the robot could not have done it, even if gpt would have easily understood the request.

To cover up the pause when the robot processes the interaction, it needs to do active listening; e.g. repeating key terms, and using vocalisations like "Uh huh". It also needs to look at the speaker, and then look at the objects. The lack of motion while the robot processes the interaction is also creepy, and can be covered up by body language, such as moving the head to make eye contact, and orienting the body towards the speaker and then the objects. It can also follow the speaker's gaze even while the speaker is talking, and move it's head to look at the same things as the speaker is looking at. These actions would make the interaction more human-like.

@@BlyatifulButter I'm not sure. While I think rogue and deviant AI will mostly be a non-issue, they will just become another sentient working class that sometimes breaks laws, much like humans, but I do think it's impossible to have fully intelligent machines that react to their environment that are not sentient. Mostly because I believe sentience is a by product of the feedback loop between our brains, our DNA (natural programming), and the environment we interact with. Once you get that feedback loop going, it's likely going to do things that eventually deviate from its programming, much like we can do things that deviate from our instincts.

@@Ristaak I agree. Sentience, so far, can only be achieved with consciousness, subjective experiences and self-awareness, something that humans are well capable of because of their intricate nervous systems and brains. AI (I‚Äôm referring to language models) on the other hand, utilize deep-learning neural networks and various algorithms to perform tasks that require human intelligence. However, such algorithms are fundamentally pre-programmed, which leads me to believe that AI will never achieve sentience, let alone deviance, especially with the latter, as that would constitute breaking its own code, which I‚Äôm certain is impossible. But who knows what might await us in the future?

My big question is this: why are we so narcissistic as a species that we almost only ever try to make HUMANOID robots? Is the human being the pinnacle of evolutionary form for some reason? Are there not dozens of much better and much easier to iterate upon forms that could accomplish the same tasks even better? Think about how many species walk on four legs vs. 2 legs. There's a very good reason most creatures do not walk upright, and yet roboticists continually insist on making 6 ft.+ tall topheavy humanoid forms. Makes very little sense from an engineering perspective.
I've seen many different forms of robots, including dogs. It makes sense that a robot that is built to do human jobs would look like a human.

@@mygirldarby Yes, Boston Dynamics has one doglike robot, but largely they are humanoid. But why? Why does it make sense that a robot doing human jobs should be humanoid? Humans are less efficient at pretty much everything compared to robots. The design should be optimized for the job. A general purpose robot (a la Primus in R.U.R.) is in principal a terrible idea that will almost certainly never come to fruition because what's the point? The point of a robot is to excel in and optimize performance in a specific narrow field. A robot who is amazing at, say, doing dishes and making food and other kitchen-related tasks would have no reason to be able to travel long distances super quickly or assemble complicated electronics or clean second-story windows etc. etc., and trying to include every function would make it prohibitively difficult to design and impossible to buy except for the absolute richest of all people. If I bought my hypothetical kitchen assistant robot that cooked and washed dishes and cleaned up the kitchen and ordered food deliveries online, I would say that it having two arms like a human would be a detriment because it could only do two things at once that way. Something more akin to a spider or octopus as a form would be far more efficient. And probably even then there are improvements to be made upon their forms since they've not evolved based on their ability to cook food specifically. The robots that replaced humans on automobile assembly lines look like big mechanical arms, not entire people, because just an arm is required to assemble car parts. That a humanoid form is in any way optimal (or even necessary) to do human jobs is entirely an unfounded assumption.

The robot speech is fake. Text-to-speech wouldn't use filler words such as 'uh', and wouldn't use false starts such as 'I th-I think'. Unless it was trained to do that, which would raise the question: Why?
Except, they would.
@@KevinAshton388 Prove it

@@existenceisillusion6528 One reason a robot might use filler words like "uh" is to signal that it is actively processing information or making decisions. In this context, "uh" can serve as a verbal placeholder while the robot analyzes data or formulates a response. For example:

"Uh, let me check the database for relevant information."
"Uh, I'm processing your request. Please wait a moment."
"I'm considering different options, uh, to determine the best course of action."

@@KevinAshton388 1) It's unnecessary, doing that adds no value, 2) what about the long delay before the initial response?, 3) if a human omitted stutters and filler words, you wouldn't notice. So again, ...way to reach!

Whilst the motion of the bot is impressive, this presentation doesn't, like others, prove anything. Until a presentation is done live and with random players (non-company participants), with randomly chosen activity in a given environment (it would have to be an environment that includes objects and potential tasks that the bot has learnt), no definitive conclusion can be drawn. This whole presentation is open to questioning as everything shown could have just been a preprogramed sequence. A live presentation, with random participants and independent observers, is the only forum that can provide anything conclusive.

@@smartFunable What is holding back humanoid robotics is neither the lack of world models (all LLMs have excellent World Models), nor is it the current lag.  That will be resolved before the end of this year.  The real obstacle is the Hardware used to run the current AI models, GPUs are the equivalent of the steam engine for AI, they are extremely energy inefficient and if placed in such a small robot they will consume the energy of its batteries in less than 1 hour, that is why those robots that understand our physical world must work with the brain in the cloud, that is why it is the Delay.  GPUs can only be placed in electric cars because the mass of 400kg of batteries is much greater than the GPU compared to the 5kg of batteries of a humanoid.  The solution exists and they are NPUs, Neuromorphic Process Units, and skillfully Sam Altman has already invested millions in companies like Rain Neuromorphic that manage this technology to precisely solve this problem, NPUs are 100 thousand times more efficient than GPUs and their neural networks. Artificial neural networks recognize patterns much faster than biological neural networks since the electrical impulse is 5 million times greater than the biochemical nervous impulse.  In other words, when robots are ready they will be better at recognizing patterns and understanding our world than their creators' own brains.  The most a current GPU in a robot can achieve is 900 Teraflops or 0.9Petaflops and consuming a lot of energy from the batteries, a typical NVIDIA GPU like the Jetson Orin reaches 0.3PFlops, the Tesla FSD chip is around 0.7PFlops, To match human speed, between 17 and 25PFlops are required and only NPUs can achieve that performance while maintaining consumption at 25 to 45W.  practically as low as the human brain.  All of this will be available after 2027 onwards due to simple market pressure, once this threshold of efficiency is reached, mass production and competition will do their magic to lower prices.  Then by 2030 the first world will begin to be filled with robots everywhere as a result of having lowered the cost per FLOP of AI.  In technology, the Exponential Law dictates, contrary to what people believe, the bigger the jump, the less time it takes.

@@The_KingDogeThe price will still be cheaper than raising a child to adulthood, and these come out of the box ready to help you out. We aren't far from building a bunch of robots and telling them, "Build more robots". Like, that will be the entire instruction. Disembodied AI will handle logistics and contracts and legal and things like leasing manufacturing spaces. These things will be driving forklifts, managing warehouses, inspecting and repairing manufacturing equipment. Designing new equipment and workflows. Optimizing every step.

It will be as simple as "come with me, I need you to fly this helicopter". It'll identify the model, perform a standard preflight walk around inspection, with a focus on issues common to that particular model as well as reviewing its maintenance history based on its markings. All without you asking it to do those things because they are encompassed by what "fly this helicopter" means.

I think the hardest part will be getting it to know when it needs to ask for help. To reduce confidence in incorrect output. The may prove to be like the halting problem.

@@peterfludde1206  No, not coded prior, yes it could have handed him a plate.

When you get into how large language models work basically they‚Äôre not coded per say, they‚Äôre ‚Äúgrown‚Äù tons of data is pumped into these models and tons of processing, then the program finds patterns within large inscruitable matrices (basically) in other worlds for instance with chat gpt, the way it responds with text, those replies aren‚Äôt programmed, they‚Äôre given out as a function of best probabilistic replies.

If I say ‚ÄúI woke up and looked out the window and noticed today it was a sunny _____‚Äù the next word would likely be predicted to be either day or morning, something like that. In a similar way, the replies are basically a probabilistic calculation like this where responses to questions are derived from these probabilities as a function of crunching a ton of math and noticing patterns within the english (or whatever else) language). Similarly the robotic movements were probably simulated with a physics model or real world model and they ran simulated movements billions of times until the model was able to sort out what worked, then this framework is utilized to inform its future movements just like a large language models probabilistic functions inform its best guesses to a string of worlds. What this robot does is expand from just language to video data movement data, lots of stuff and combines these models together into something that processes a bunch of these aspects. 

For more on that just look into how large language models work online, and you‚Äôll see, by analogy, how this is working.

It‚Äôs not ‚Äúthinking‚Äù per say, it‚Äôs basically crunched so much data that it has an internal theory of movement language etc which it utilizes to give feedback in response to the video and audio data. This theory of movement is so complicated and unimaginable by human standards because the unimaginable amounts of data and processing that went into it. In the past we tried to program all these details but it never turned out right, this way the computer can just do it itself and find its own patterns and basically we don‚Äôt understand its own programming or the patterns it has found.

It‚Äôs basically predicting is all, based on past inputs/data which was used to form a framework for what is likely to come next.

Another example is spell check as I type this, the phone is predicting likely words I might type and listing them as options.. same concept just incomprehensibly larger/more compex

Without seeing this scenario performed with just some random person put in a room with the robot, then I'm not all that impressed.  Much of this could have been painstakingly trained.  Some of the questionable aspects is picking up the plate.  The plate wasn't placed into a random location.  Nor was the apple.  The trash was, which would be far easier for the robot to pickup than the other two objects.  How about the drying rack, is it specifically recognizing the locations to put the cup and plate, or was that based on where the rack was always positioned and the exact location it was told to put it?  Could it do this with any object, or was it specifically trained on these objects for hundreds or thousands of hours?

How about that little toss of the apple to the man?  Did it recognize his hand and toss it into his hand, or was it trained to pick it up, move it over, and then drop it.  The man's hand was already moving to the position the robot would have dropped the apple to catch it.  Looks real impressive, and our only choice is to assume the robot did in fact the apple to the man, but we don't know that for sure.  Do it again, without the man reaching for it and see if the robot drops the apple anyways so we know for sure whether or not the robot is recognizing the situation.

If Tesla and Elon Musk have taught us anything, people will often default to belief of anything they see or hear.  That's stagecraft.  A robot picking up a randomly placed shirt and folding it is incredible.  What we didn't see is the person just off camera literally controlling all of the arm movements and the robot wasn't in fact "seeing" or moving anything on its own .  How is this video from Figure any different?  We don't know what we don't know.  Maybe the robot and objects were setup there for the first time and it accomplished all of this the first time.  To that I'd say... not likely... but it's possible.

A human could walk up to that table in front of those objects for the first time and do everything this robot did.  The robot likely has been standing in front of that table for thousands of hours repeating this scenario over and over again... because that's how machine learning works... and probably still can't deal with unexpected situations.  What if a paper ball fell off the plate and onto the ground?  What if the robot clipped the plate on the rack and it slipped out of its hand?  The robot hit the rack when it was putting its hand down after moving the plate.  What if the robot hitting the rack knocked all of the items over and now it had to move them back into place?  

We don't know what we don't know, and this video did little to assuage our questions about the true abilities of this robot and AI.

Amazing. Continuous video stream, continuous audio stream. Detect keywords 'Figure1', begin recording audio. Detect when sentence is finished, capture audio wav file. Speech to Text via OpenAI Whisper API, hence the latency in response. Prompt OpenAI GPT-4 for response with STT response, prompt engineered to act like a robotic assistant. Likely OpenAI TTS for voice, but could be ElevenLabs as well, another latency contributor. Snapshot captured from video stream, image analyzed with OpenAI GPT-4 for scene description. Maybe an additional Segment Anything type model to identify objects in scene. Another custom neural net to generate robot movements according to objects in scene. Depth perception provided by Lidar in the head? Maybe, but could be stereo cameras and another neural net fed into the loop.

Once there is hardware that can run OpenAI models locally on Figure1, things will really pick up. Movement will be instantaneous and natural. Still incredible stuff so far.

I'd love to work here :)

You either missed the end-to-end neural networks and speech-to-speech in the video description or you don‚Äôt understand the concept. As I understand the description, this is a single vision-language-action model just as VLA concept in Google DeepMind papers. When the input is only a microphone and cameras, and then a single model interprets requests into actions and response speech through speakers. If this is true, then this is a truly amazing result.

Found Corey Lynch's tweets on the topic. It confirms that the microphone data is transcribed into text (possibly using Whisper), plus images captured from cameras are taken, then the images and texts are put into one model, which then returns a text response (then converted from text to speech), as well as the actions required to be performed by the robot.

What is also remarkable is the self-correction. So, when Figure  put the plate into the drying rack, the plate wobbled a bit, and you could see Figures arm already moving towards the plate to stabilize it. However, the action was prematurely halted as the wobbling ceased. Incredible.

You can see the hand clip the rack, so it moved its hand up and away from the rack before putting it down.  Likely wasn't doing anything with the plate; just a coincidence.  We really have no idea how many times the ai was trained on this scenario.  My guess is it was many times before it got it right, and this video may have been shot many times before it got it perfect.  It's machine learning; it learns the correct solution by trial and error and correction.  So they likely repeated and corrected this scenario many times before it finally started getting it right.

@@naaspam1185Yeah, it is hard to say. However, if you look at 1X's recent video "All Neural Networks. All Autonomous. All 1X speed" you'll see that company has a whole bunch of robots doing various repetitive tasks over and over again, all at the same time, like placing a block in a basket that falls down into a tray, to place back in again. They prove the point that they have some amount of reliability with theirs, since there'd be no way to make that video if they were constantly failing at the tasks. You may also want to see the recent video on Covariant's RFM-1, which is a robot arm that does object picking in a factory, but has impressive capabilities and rolling out into production soon it seems.

@@naaspam1185 you're misunderstanding what you're seeing. It wasn't trained on this exact scenario, it's improvising from its available "action bank" aka muscle memory aka bank of pre-trained body motions. The LLM is acting as brain for the body and mapping action commands to a policy network to move the body. It has learned the generic skills of picking things up, not this specific scenario practiced over and over. Body and brain are completely different systems just integrated the same way we're all using LLM's to execution functions in apps. That body is just another app to the LLM.
VLM in this case, not LLM@@Gnaritas42

@@AlphaMachina  IMO, it just means the sensors are quite sensitive.  It was taught to pull its hand back with minimal pressure with the first sign of contact to stop movement and reverse course.  I don't know if that's exactly impressive.

It's impressive, but it's 20+ years in the making, and isn't necessarily anything this particular company did or solved on their own.

Without seeing what exactly went into this presentation, I'm just not really seeing anything new.  The hardware is obviously well done, but this presentation only showed minimal capabilities. @@slimerone My major issue with the concept of AGI is that it assumes that we've settled the mind body problem which we haven't. The brain itself keeps becoming more and more complex from our point of view as the years go on. For instances we've recently discovered that there are 3000+ cells within the brain. How will we ever be able to tell if the machine is conscious or merely mimicking us? While I definitely do see the AI fields making great advances I think some of the philosophical pre suppositions about AGI are faulty. Another issue I have is that if this is powered by Chat GBT then it is not on a path to self awareness. Chat GBT can explain why it gives you answers just like this can, but it doesn't actual have a understanding of the coherent concepts. For example LLM hallucinations are a major problem. It will give you a what appears to be great answer, but the vast majority of its information is fake. If you correct it upon the topic it will agree with you showing that it lacks any actual understanding of the topic or awareness of its words. I've seen some people like the woman who left google call it a "strong word calculator" or "auto correct on steroids". To my knowledge this applies to all LLMs as well. I could rant on more, but I don't want to write a essay.

‚Äã@@slimerone Sorry for coming off as hostile. Anyways I'll give a couple reasons why I don't think AGI is even a feasible concept right now. To know if something is consciousness or possess the ability to conceive abstract thought, we'd need to understand how we'd receive consciousness to begin with. We have no idea what consciousness is or how we have it. Is it an emergent property of the brain? If that so how do you explain qualia, and if you close your eyes you can picture redness. You can open up your brain at that moment and examine it with our current technology. You will however never understand how a person can picture redness within their mind or why that can occur. All you can understand is the process of how red objects appear to them. Another major issue in my opinion is the NDEs people go through when they are brain dead, yet there are records of them hovering above their bodies and being able to perfectly give information out to the doctors surrounding them. If a physicalist theory of the mind is true I would have a problem more so with the AGI timeline due to our ever-evolving understanding of our brain. 

I am quite aware of the qualities of exponential growth, but I think it will lead to diminishing returns at some point. I will use the various console generations as a example. Each generation saw a uptick in technological progress with each generation becoming stronger and stronger. Many people questioned why the PS5 isn't much different from the ps4 visually despite all around improvements in all areas of technology. While the chips have experienced exponential power increase the actual graphics received diminishing returns at the same time. I don't know if this is a good example admittedly, but it's one I can think of were exponential growth did not have the desired effects with a technology industry.

My third and final reason as to why I don't believe this will result in AI is purely based off my speculation that its using chat gpt or a similar LLM to power it. The authors of "On the Dangers of Stochastic Parrots: Can Language Models Be Too Big?" had recently gone on the Adam conways podcast to discuss problems with Chat gpt. They cite that it actually can't think at all, and that it is a "word calculator". A example of this is the hallucinations it does. It will create fake citations, arguments, and people all to support its answer. When questioned about this it either doubles down or says you're right and corrects itself. The fact that it does this is evidence that LLMs don't understand abstract concepts or arguments. It doesn't actually understand the material to give you a good answer. If it doubles down then it clearly has no idea what it's even spouting out, nor can it actually justify its thinking. If it agrees with you the reasoning is largely the same. It has no real understanding of the world, nor does it have any understanding of languages. Noam Chomsky has also noted similar critiques to its ability to understand languages and its abstract thinking capabilities. 

Sorry for the mini essay I just wanted to get my thoughts across. Again sorry for coming off as hostile I'm kinda sick of the AI hype and having to deal with techbros promising a future utopia right around the corner.

It has no real understanding of the world, nor does it have any understanding of languages. Noam Chomsky has also noted similar critiques to its ability to understand languages and its abstract thinking capabilities.
