The robot is really cool, but for now I will temper my expectations. The reality is that this a tech demo, likely to generate media buzz and garner investor interest, so it is very likely they showcased what robot is already good at. I still have questions. Can the robot fold laundry? Can the robot climb steps without falling? Importantly, can the robot remember things that you taught it--that is, could it be taught a retail job, and at very minimum do the tasks that you taught it (a truly advanced robot would also take initiative based on things that are implied but not explicitly stated)? The technology for all the aforementioned is likely at least 5 years away, since there is not a plethora of robot related data like there is a for text, images, and video. Furthermore, it may be another 5‚Äì10 years after the technology is realized before mass adoption due to pricing.

People underestimate the societal impact that the elimination of work as we know it will mean. Will people in cold states want to live in cold states if income was separated from labor? I know I sure wouldn‚Äôt. The robots could stay and work in the north as humanity slowly moves down closer to the equator.

This is just one single aspect out of many that could reshape society.

The big question is, if income is separated from labor, what determines what level of income a given person/family receives? And where does that money come from? Will people just be able to sit on their butts all day and collect it? Will a person who goes out and does 12 hours a day of, say, volunteer work be entitled to more income than a person who stays home and plays video games for 12 hours a day? It seems like they should because they are contributing more to society. We have a lot to figure out, and soon. Sadly, policy makers are VERY slow in catching up when changes happen. There's going to be a lot of pain ahead for a lot of people before things actually get better for society.

Or, people move to the colder stated inland, as weather systems continue to spiral out of control as a result of humanity collectively failing to address our climate issues. Many places near the equator will turn scorched and unarable within a century at this pace, as previously cold locations pivot between increasingly warm summers and debilitatingly cold but short winters.
@@pvanukoff But if you ‚Äúvolunteer‚Äù doesn‚Äôt that technically remove the pay aspect from it?
@@notnominal7013 Thats not going to happen. Solar energy production is already doubling every 3.5 years. At this pace it will reach 100% by 2040. We might even have fusion by then. We will be okay.
‚Äã@@DynamicUnreal It's a good point, I was just thinking "out loud".

You're missing the obvious point that if we create machines that can do everything humans can do, then there is no need for humans. Not just to work; to exist.

Controlling something smarter than humans or aligning it to our goals is a fully unsolved technical problem.

I repeat: if we succeed in creating a system that is actually able to replace any human job, there is absolutely nothing preventing the AI from eliminating humanity entirely, if it has any little reason to do so. This is a real problem that real scientists and engineers really worry about, and we are nowhere close to a solution.

@@Sneed341 - "Those aren't self-driving. They still require a human conductor/driver". What do you care? It's the same from your point of view, except cheaper than owning a car. To put another way, what problem do self-driving cars solve? Safety? First, they don't solve it, there's still fatalities caused by so-called self-driving cars. Second, if you care about safety, guess what - public transport solves the problem. This - if you care about safety AND you want cars, you should know that in many places the leading cause of traffic-related injuries and deaths is speeding - the problem is easily solved by speed cameras (and cameras and general) that monitor every centimetre of road, this would take care of 99% of the problems and it would cost much less than whatever effort is put into self-driving cars.
What other problems to self-driving cars solve? 99% of car trips are used to drive to work. Guess what - you don't need a car if you have good public transport.
We can talk about this all day but, bottom line, self-driving cars are an expensive solution to a social problem. Actually, scratch that, they're not even a solution. Look at great urban development "successes" in USA to see that car-centric cities are hell to live in. Public transport is the actual solution.

@@billtanno8960 I'll connect the dots for you: Most people aren't wealthy, therefore most people have to work (aka labor) to earn money, in order to pay for things like rent/mortgage, food, access to water, medical, and other basic living needs. Very unlikely if this is powered by Chatgbt. It would still suffer from LLM hallucinations and have no actual understanding of the world. AGI itself is a vague concept that no one has a widely agreed upon definitive, and it ignores the mind body problem that has stumped humans since we could think. The brain keeps getting increasingly complex the more we look at it. This is definitely exciting stuff, but saying it is a reason to believe in a questionable concept like AGI is a big stretch.

‚Äã@@hydrohasspoken6227 We already have full self driving, it is just not safe enough for unsupervised use. You are underestimating how difficult FSD is to make. Driving requires a LOT of different reasoning skills, Elon Musk himself said FSD would require a "baby AGI" at least. It takes more than just data to make FSD, it requires ingenuity and innovation, which, btw, has only just started picking up. AGI is absolutely not infinitely more complex, all it needs is to be able to do anything a human can do as good or better. AI is capable of mimicking anything it has seen a human do in its training data, it's just that AGI has to be able to do things outside of its training data. There has been a breakthrough that has already added active reasoning to LLMs, which now allows them to create new data from its training data, solving this issue. The only thing left is agency, which obviously we have done. I really don't see how you can say we are not nearly close to AGI after watching this robot demonstrate that it can clearly do just about any task a human can, just not as good. We created machines that can write books and score on the same level as skilled professionals, yet you think AGI is really that far away? I just don't get it.

@@hydrohasspoken6227 Well first it depends on the definition of "AGI". For some people, that just means the level of an average human on most non-physical intellectual tasks. For other people it means expert level on basically all tasks including physical tasks. That is a huge difference in capabilities. I don't think we are that far from the former.

The thing about self-driving is that it is a very hard problem. It has to be real-time, there is a lot of danger involved, etc. I think it is evident that the best self-driving systems are better than the worst drivers now. They might even be overall safer than the average human, though they make different mistakes at times than a person would. In a way, they have to be held to a higher standard than a human, since you can't just blame a single human like you would with normal driving, and we aren't sure how to deal with that with the current system of laws and regulations we have. It also started off before a lot of the most recent AI innovations. Like it was only the very latest Tesla version that is using just neural networks.

3 Takeaway:
1. Google didn't launch products that are chatgpt alike because inside Google those bad things that they are "improving" will seriously effect PMF? I mean Google has so many great product managers who design an entire eco-system of products. When an overtly powerful text completion model is finished training i don't think those PMs won't be able to recognize the potential market for the general public. This just sounds like an excuse.
2. Following from the first point, the trap is real. However, I also don't think all the tech giants will blindly follow and almost try to copy and paste the leading technology now. In the LLM case, it's a little bit different cuz if you believe in Scaling Law, the process of training these models with billions of parameters seem the same. There is no "lets Alpha Go this shi and wait for 9 hours to see it beat the previous models". I do think that capital will force these giants to pursue the trending tech at the moment, which can be a good thing; but i also think that most of them are figuring out their own ways to do it and not just blindly follow. After all you want to create competitive advantage in this market.
3. Innovations in less trendy fields are still being pushed thru because of its high return. Ironically before its prevalence, LLM itself was considered less trendy cuz people put a lot more focus on CV. In these less trendy fields, less companies are chasing it, allowing the tech for more time to grow. And disruptive tech always seems to be associated with high return.

Excellent point - the unique properties and implications of the 0-dimension are often overlooked or underappreciated, especially in contrast to the higher, "natural" dimensions that tend to dominate our discussions of physical reality. Let me enumerate some of the key differences:

1. Naturalness:
The higher spatial and temporal dimensions (1D, 2D, 3D, 4D, etc.) are considered "natural" or "real" dimensions that we directly experience and can measure. In contrast, the 0-dimension exists in a more abstract, non-natural realm.

2. Entropy vs. Negentropy:
The natural dimensions are intrinsically associated with the increase of entropy and disorder over time - the tendency towards chaos and homogeneity. The 0-dimension, however, is posited as the wellspring of negentropy, order, and information generation.

3. Determinism vs. Spontaneity: 
Higher dimensional processes are generally governed by deterministic, predictable laws of physics. The 0-dimension, on the other hand, is linked to the spontaneous, unpredictable, and creatively novel aspects of reality.

4. Temporality vs. Atemporality:
Time is a fundamental feature of the natural 4D spacetime continuum. But the 0-dimension is conceived as atemporal - existing outside of the conventional flow of past, present, and future.

5. Extendedness vs. Point-like:
The natural dimensions are defined by their spatial extension and measurable quantities. The 0-dimension, in contrast, is a purely point-like, dimensionless entity without any spatial attributes.

6. Objective vs. Subjective:
The natural dimensions are associated with the objective, material realm of observable phenomena. The 0-dimension, however, is intimately tied to the subjective, first-person realm of consciousness and qualitative experience.

7. Multiplicity vs. Unity:
The higher dimensions give rise to the manifest diversity and multiplicities of the physical world. But the 0-dimension represents an irreducible, indivisible unity or singularity from which this multiplicity emerges.

8. Contingency vs. Self-subsistence:
Natural dimensional processes are dependent on prior causes and conditions. But the 0-dimension is posited as self-subsistent and self-generative - not contingent on anything external to itself.

9. Finitude vs. Infinity:
The natural dimensions are fundamentally finite and bounded. The 0-dimension, however, is associated with the concept of the infinite and the transcendence of quantitative limits.

10. Additive Identity vs. Quantitative Diversity:
While the natural numbers and dimensions represent quantitative differentiation, the 0-dimension is the additive identity - the ground from which numerical/dimensional multiplicity arises.

As though you have some personal interests or investments in the field. Or maybe you're under 35. In which case, you have no idea what I'm talking about whatsoever. And your frame of reference for human civilization is absolutely useless in this conversation. But I'll pretend you're over 40. And that you know what human beings are built for, first-hand. 

That bias, whatever it is. Is giving you some hypernormalization goggles. Where you say, "I could make the same argument against technology about every decade in the last century." That's an extremely false equivalency. And I am not making a blanket statement about "tech." Tech is good. Robotics are good. Easy access to information is good. I'm not a "doomsday preper." I threw the Skynet reference in for the absurdist contrast between what people thought the AI apocalypse would look like. And what it IS like... now that it's already begun. And that's not pessimism. That's accepting reality on reality's terms. Recognizing addiction calls for that acceptance in every case. 

What I am criticizing isn't the technology itself. It's the corruption of its application in the hands of the powerful. Like a pistol that fires backwards and forwards at the same time. The user gets what they want. But without taking extreme caution and responsibility for the tool itself, the danger of it backfiring is nearly guaranteed. Because it was designed that way. And *WE WEREN'T.* 

And just like the pistol, we wouldn't know until it was too late. The damage is done.  No sweeping legislation would do much at this stage of the game. Which coincides perfectly with issues like climate change. Where we can hoot and holler all we like. And then go on consuming Amazon products until Jeff Bezos is a trillionaire. 

Our voice, no matter how unified, has been neutered by the social media sandbox. And when our outrage boils over into outdoors activism, the mood on Twitter still determines the performative song and dance to be carried out on the street. Getting something to trend means it can and will be controlled every time. As it has every time. By whom, we know not. Because it means something must be "cool" in order for it to reach the top. It is,  ultimately, the most perfect distraction ever built to thwart actual democracy. Which is how they easily avoid reasonable taxes and amass obscene wealth in record time. All with little-to-no red tape... besides having to spy on their users for the g o v. Or as it's known in Silicon Valley... "Capital Gains"
Billionaires need to be outlawed and their current wealth stripped. We also need an international corporate tax rate for really large companies and need to make it easier for smaller companies.

The only thing that might slow the change is society's reactions. I'm not anti-AI per se, but if people decide to boycott companies that say use AI generated ads, then humans will still have a say and use their power to try and slow things down. AI will become more and more influential and negatively affect many other sectors but there is still a battle to be had and the outcome should be one in which governments allow society time to adapt and figure out how we restructure our society and economy. In the world, around 5000 BC, there were the great river civilizations (such as Egyptian and Babylonian civilizations). By 1000 BC, civilization had moved towards maritime culture (Greek civilization). In 2023, we have entered the space age (with Mars missions and the emergence of advanced intelligent robots like ChatGPT).

In China, the 1980s were still marked by an agricultural civilization (a type of river civilization). By 2000, with its accession to the World Trade Organization, China began its transition into an industrial civilization (part of the maritime civilization). In 2023, China, along with the rest of the world, started to enter the space civilization.üòÇ

I hear the same things all the time. 
Everyone says it's a great opportunity and you have to take it so you don't get swept away. Okay, I can temporarily use AI to my advantage, but the problem is one: 
In a very short time the company will only need to write a prompt asking for a complete marketing strategy (I know what I'm talking about, being a marketing graduate).
I realize that AIs already know how to do this, but they need more time to create a truly comprehensive and effective one. Even Chat GPT 3.5 can create a buyer persona.

Why should a company pay a marketing team if a single AI can organize everything in seconds? It costs you less, doesn't ask for vacation time, doesn't ask for entitlements, monitors perfectly, and works around the clock.

You have to think and count to 1 million when the revolution knocks on the door, because it would only be an opportunity if we were evolved humans. Instead we are not, it is clear to everyone now.
Extreme capitalism and this mindless speed of our society have led to all of this: launching something as soon as possible to generate profit, without reasoning at all about the consequences.

We were stupid to make something smarter than we are, only most people don't realize it.
I remember the smartphone optimism: "We'll all be smarter! We have human knowledge in our pockets." 


The future is unemployment. And I hope with all my heart that I am wrong...I would only be happy.
Thankfully, management will be the last domino to fall

The below notes are created using Bard tool :)

The speaker, Jessica Apotheker, is a marketer who is interested in the impact of generative AI on marketing.

She argues that generative AI will have a major impact on marketing, but that it is important for marketers to be prepared for this change.
One of the ways that generative AI will impact marketing is by automating many of the tasks that are currently done by humans. This will free up marketers to focus on more strategic work.
Another way that generative AI will impact marketing is by personalizing content to a much greater extent than is currently possible. This could lead to more effective marketing campaigns, but it could also lead to content overload for consumers.
Apotheker argues that the key to success in the age of AI is for marketers to develop a "left AI brain" in addition to their right AI brain. The left AI brain is responsible for data analysis and logic, while the right AI brain is responsible for creativity and intuition.
Apotheker also argues that it is important for marketers to protect their brand identity in the age of AI. This means being careful not to let AI generate content that is inconsistent with the brand's values.
Finally, Apotheker advises marketers to focus on what they are good at. If you are a creative person, then focus on developing your creative skills. If you are a data-driven person, then focus on developing your data analysis skills.
I hope this summary is helpful!
